The following statement contains a magic number: foreach (Particle p in particles) {  	// skip inactive particles  	if (!p.Active)  		continue;  	// normalized lifetime is a value from 0 to 1 and represents how far  	// a particle is through its life. 0 means it just started' .5 is half  	// way through' and 1.0 means it's just about to be finished.  	// this value will be used to calculate alpha and scale' to avoid   	// having particles suddenly appear or disappear.  	float normalizedLifetime = p.TimeSinceStart / p.Lifetime;  	// we want particles to fade in and fade out' so we'll calculate alpha  	// to be (normalizedLifetime) * (1-normalizedLifetime). this way' when  	// normalizedLifetime is 0 or 1' alpha is 0. the maximum value is at  	// normalizedLifetime = .5' and is  	// (normalizedLifetime) * (1-normalizedLifetime)  	// (.5)                 * (1-.5)  	// .25  	// since we want the maximum alpha to be 1' not .25' we'll scale the   	// entire equation by 4.  	float alpha = 4 * normalizedLifetime * (1 - normalizedLifetime);  	Color color = Color.White * alpha;  	// make particles grow as they age. they'll start at 75% of their size'  	// and increase to 100% once they're finished.  	float scale = p.Scale * (.75f + .25f * normalizedLifetime);  	game.SpriteBatch.Draw (texture' p.Position' null' color' p.Rotation' origin' scale' SpriteEffects.None' 0.0f);  }
